input:
1. A 14-year-old male presents with a two-year history of progressive weakness and wasting of the distal muscles in his hands and feet, accompanied by frequent falls while walking. He reports difficulty in dorsiflexion of his ankles, leading to a high-stepping gait, and complains of occasional numbness and tingling in his toes. On examination, there is marked muscle atrophy in the intrinsic hand muscles and anterior lower legs, pes cavus deformity, and diminished deep tendon reflexes. Sensory testing reveals decreased vibration and proprioception distally. His father has a similar but milder neuropathy with foot deformities, suggesting a family history. Nerve conduction studies demonstrate markedly reduced conduction velocities, consistent with a demyelinating neuropathy. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the MFN2 gene, consistent with Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 7. The patient is referred for physical therapy and orthotic support to manage symptoms and improve mobility.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: I should explain my problems clearly but honestly, even if I feel a little embarrassed or confused about what’s wrong. I want the doctor to understand I’ve been having these weird feelings and trouble walking for a long time.

ANSWER: Um, I’m 14 and I’m a guy. Well, I’ve been kind of falling a lot when I walk and my hands and feet feel all weird and weak, like they’re wasting away, I guess. It’s been happening for a couple of years now, and I just feel kinda shaky and off-balance all the time.

input: 1. A 14-year-old male presents with a two-year history of progressive weakness and wasting of the distal muscles in his hands and feet, accompanied by frequent falls while walking. He reports difficulty in dorsiflexion of his ankles, leading to a high-stepping gait, and complains of occasional numbness and tingling in his toes. On examination, there is marked muscle atrophy in the intrinsic hand muscles and anterior lower legs, pes cavus deformity, and diminished deep tendon reflexes. Sensory testing reveals decreased vibration and proprioception distally. His father has a similar but milder neuropathy with foot deformities, suggesting a family history. Nerve conduction studies demonstrate markedly reduced conduction velocities, consistent with a demyelinating neuropathy. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the MFN2 gene, consistent with Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 7. The patient is referred for physical therapy and orthotic support to manage symptoms and improve mobility.Can you tell me more about how these symptoms affect your day-to-day life, and if you've noticed any changes or patterns in how they come and go?
output: Um, well, I guess it’s been pretty hard lately. I get tired really fast, especially when I try to walk or stand for a long time. Sometimes my feet feel numb, like pins and needles, I think. And I keep falling, even if I don’t feel like I was about to. It’s not really clear if it gets worse at certain times — it’s just kind of there all the time, I guess.

input: 1. A 14-year-old male presents with a two-year history of progressive weakness and wasting of the distal muscles in his hands and feet, accompanied by frequent falls while walking. He reports difficulty in dorsiflexion of his ankles, leading to a high-stepping gait, and complains of occasional numbness and tingling in his toes. On examination, there is marked muscle atrophy in the intrinsic hand muscles and anterior lower legs, pes cavus deformity, and diminished deep tendon reflexes. Sensory testing reveals decreased vibration and proprioception distally. His father has a similar but milder neuropathy with foot deformities, suggesting a family history. Nerve conduction studies demonstrate markedly reduced conduction velocities, consistent with a demyelinating neuropathy. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the MFN2 gene, consistent with Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 7. The patient is referred for physical therapy and orthotic support to manage symptoms and improve mobility.Can you tell me more about what your symptoms feel like day-to-day, how they've changed over time, and if there’s anything that seems to make them better or worse?
output: Um, well, it’s been kind of weird. Like, my hands and feet get really weak, and I drop stuff now sometimes, even stuff I’m holding tight. It’s worse when I do a lot of walking or stand for a long time, and I fall a lot now. Sometimes my toes feel numb or tingly, and I don’t know, I guess it’s kind of the same most days, but it’s been getting a little worse over time, I think. I haven’t really noticed anything that helps or makes it worse, really.

input: 1. A 14-year-old male presents with a two-year history of progressive weakness and wasting of the distal muscles in his hands and feet, accompanied by frequent falls while walking. He reports difficulty in dorsiflexion of his ankles, leading to a high-stepping gait, and complains of occasional numbness and tingling in his toes. On examination, there is marked muscle atrophy in the intrinsic hand muscles and anterior lower legs, pes cavus deformity, and diminished deep tendon reflexes. Sensory testing reveals decreased vibration and proprioception distally. His father has a similar but milder neuropathy with foot deformities, suggesting a family history. Nerve conduction studies demonstrate markedly reduced conduction velocities, consistent with a demyelinating neuropathy. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the MFN2 gene, consistent with Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 7. The patient is referred for physical therapy and orthotic support to manage symptoms and improve mobility.Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started, how they’ve changed over time, and if there’s anything that seems to make them better or worse?
output: Well, I think I started noticing my feet feeling kind of weird maybe about two years ago, like they’d tingle and sometimes go numb. At first, it was just sometimes, but lately it’s been worse—like I fall more often and my legs feel really tired. I don’t really know if anything makes it better; sometimes rest helps, but not always. It just seems to keep getting worse, I think.

The patient is referred for physical therapy and orthotic support to manage symptoms and improve mobility.Is there any family history of neurological conditions, inherited neuropathies, or similar symptoms in relatives? Also, were there any recent illnesses, infections, or immunizations preceding the onset of your symptoms?
output: Uh, yeah, my dad has something similar… he has foot problems and a little weakness too, but it was milder. As for recent illnesses or vaccines, I don’t really remember anything like that happening before I started feeling this way. Nothing I can think of anyway.

output: Um, I think it’s mostly been pretty slow and steady, but sometimes I feel worse than other days, and then it’s kind of the same again. I haven’t really had any sudden bad days or anything that just went away fast.

output: Um, yeah, sometimes I feel like I might fall if I’m on uneven ground or if I try to go faster. And, I think walking uphill or not on flat surfaces makes it worse, like I get more tired or my feet feel weird.
